headline: Trump says Republicans should 'probably' be afraid of him if their views are not in line with his, saying his 'unparalleled' endorsements are vital for GOP wins
author: Cheryl Teh
sentences: Brody asked Trump how he thought the upcoming elections would play out and "how much stock" he would put in recent wins for the candidates he's endorsed  particularly Ohio senate candidate JD Vance, who won his primary early this week.
And one of the candidates Trump endorsed, Sean Parnell, a GOP candidate for the Pennsylvania Senate, was forced to drop out of the race after allegations of domestic violence emerged.

Former President Donald Trump this week appeared to issue a warning that Republicans not aligned with him would lose their races if they did not correct course.
But the spate of wins may not be as much due to Trump as it is to preexisting party affiliations in areas where his endorsements are running.
However, other Trump-backed candidates, including Georgia gubernatorial candidate David Perdue, have struggled to keep up in their races.
Trump made the comments during an interview with David Brody on the Christian Broadcasting Network's television program "The 700 Club."
Trump endorsed several candidates the GOP might view as risky, including Vance and Dr. Mehmet Oz, whose primary is later this month.
Still, according to The Washington Post, 42 of the 43 candidates Trump's endorsed who have primaried already have won their races.
In the Idaho gubernatorial primary, Trump backed Janice McGeachin, who is trailing by around 40 points behind incumbent Gov.
Trump has made 160 endorsements since leaving office, per Ballotpedia, the bulk of which still have yet to play out.

Trump said Republicans should "probably" fear him if their views aren't in line with his.
Former President Donald Trump speaks to supporters at a rally on April 2, 2022, near Washington, Michigan.
As The Post's Aaron Blake noted: "He has overwhelmingly endorsed candidates who were going to win anyway."
Most of the candidates he's endorsed who have already won their primaries were incumbents, Blake added.
"Should Republicans be afraid of you, the ones that are not in line with you and your views?"
However, some Trump candidates have still struggled in their races despite his backing.
"Because if I endorsed them, they win, and if I don't endorse them, they don't win.
Perdue is 26 points behind his GOP rival, Brian Kemp, according to some pollsters.
Oz currently holds a slight 3-point lead against his fellow Republican candidates.
